factoid: Nicholas Rostov remained at his post.
Nicholas Rostov was waiting for the wolf.
The hunt approached and receded.
The cries of the dogs were familiar to Nicholas Rostov.
The voices of the huntsmen approached, receded, and rose.
Nicholas Rostov realized what was happening at the copse.
Young wolves were present at the copse.
Old wolves were present at the copse.
The hounds had separated into two packs.
A wolf was being chased somewhere.
Something had gone wrong at the copse.
Nicholas Rostov expected the wolf to come his way at any moment.
Nicholas Rostov made thousands of conjectures about where the wolf would come from.
Nicholas Rostov made thousands of conjectures about how he would set upon the wolf.
Hope alternated with despair for Nicholas Rostov.
Nicholas Rostov addressed a prayer to God.
Nicholas Rostov prayed that the wolf should come his way.
Nicholas Rostov prayed with passionate and shamefaced feeling.
Nicholas Rostov said to God, "What would it be to Thee to do this for me?"
Nicholas Rostov said to God, "I know Thou art great, and that it is a sin to ask this of Thee."
Nicholas Rostov said to God, "but for God's sake do let the old wolf come my way."
Nicholas Rostov said to God, "and let Karáy spring at it—in sight of Uncle who is watching from over there—and seize it by the throat in a death grip."
Nicholas Rostov cast eager and restless glances over the edge of the wood.
Two scraggy oaks rose above the aspen undergrowth.
The gully had a water-worn side.
Uncle's cap was visible above the bush on Nicholas Rostov's right.
Nicholas Rostov thought, "No, I shan't have such luck."
Nicholas Rostov thought, "yet what wouldn't it be worth!"
Nicholas Rostov thought, "It is not to be!"
Nicholas Rostov thought, "Everywhere, at cards and in war, I am always unlucky."
Memories of Austerlitz flashed through Nicholas Rostov's mind.
Memories of Dólokhov flashed through Nicholas Rostov's mind.
Nicholas Rostov wanted only one old wolf.
Nicholas Rostov looked left and right.
Nicholas Rostov listened to the slightest variation of note in the cries of the dogs.
Nicholas Rostov saw something running toward him across the deserted field.
Nicholas Rostov thought, "No, it can’t be!"
Nicholas Rostov took a deep breath.
The height of happiness was reached for Nicholas Rostov.
The wolf ran forward.
The wolf jumped heavily over a gully that lay in its path.
The wolf was an old animal with a gray back and big reddish belly.
The wolf ran without hurry.
The wolf felt sure that no one saw the wolf.
Nicholas Rostov held his breath.
Nicholas Rostov looked round at the borzois.
The borzois stood or lay not seeing the wolf.
The borzois did not understand the situation.
Old Karáy turned his head.
Old Karáy was angrily searching for fleas.
Old Karáy baring his yellow teeth.
Old Karáy snapped at his hind legs.
Nicholas Rostov whispered "Ulyulyulyu!"
The borzois jumped up.
The rings of the leashes jerked.
The borzois pricked their ears.
Karáy finished scratching his hindquarters.
Karáy cocked his ears.
Karáy got up with a quivering tail.
Karáy's tufts of matted hair hung down.
Nicholas Rostov asked himself, "Shall I loose them or not?"
The wolf approached Nicholas Rostov coming from the copse.
The wolf's physiognomy changed.
The wolf shuddered.
The wolf saw human eyes fixed upon the wolf.
The wolf turned its head a little toward Nicholas Rostov.
The wolf paused.
The wolf seemed to say to herself, "Back or forward? Eh, no matter, forward..."
The wolf moved forward without looking round again.
The wolf moved forward with a quiet, long, easy yet resolute lope.
Nicholas Rostov cried "Ulyulyu!" in a voice not his own.
Nicholas Rostov's horse darted headlong downhill.
Nicholas Rostov's horse leaped over gullies.
Nicholas Rostov's horse headed off the wolf.
The borzois passed Nicholas Rostov's horse, running faster still.
Nicholas Rostov did not hear his own cry.
Nicholas Rostov did not feel that he was galloping.
Nicholas Rostov did not see the borzois.
Nicholas Rostov did not see the ground over which he went.
Nicholas Rostov saw only the wolf.
The wolf increased its speed.
The wolf bounded on in the same direction along the hollow.
Mílka appeared first in view.
Mílka had black markings.
Mílka had powerful quarters.
Mílka gained upon the wolf.
Mílka was ahead of the wolf.
The wolf turned its head to face Mílka.
The wolf did not put on speed as it usually did.
Mílka raised her tail.
Mílka stiffened her forelegs.
Nicholas Rostov shouted "Ulyulyulyulyu!"
